labDescription: At the BCI4Kids Engineering lab in the BME Department, we aim to translate the evolving brain-computer interface space for children. We are focused on the multitude of digital engineering problems facing BCI translation to children: from digital signal processing, machine learning, and analysis of neurophysiological signals, to the development of engaging, exciting applications for children to play with BCI systems.

name: Mariana P Branco
title: Dr.
imageAltText: Image of Mariana P Branco smiling. She is a white woman with shoulder length brown hair with crossed hands, in front of a railing in a medical building.
shortDescription: AMariana P. Branco is an Assistant Professor at the University Medical Center Utrecht, specializing in neurotechnology and Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs). She earned her Ph.D. in Clinical and Experimental Neurosciences at UMC Utrecht, focusing on the clinical translation of implanted BCIs for communication in severe paralysis. Her research explores brain signal decoding, user-centered BCI design, and the feasibility of implanted BCIs for children with complex needs. She has authored over 30 publications, serves as editor for Frontiers in Human Neuroscience and Frontiers for Young Minds, leads a outreach program about the brain for kids, and currently serves as board member of the BCI Society.
affiliations: Department of Neurology and Neurosurgery, University Medical Center (UMC) Utrecht Brain Center, The Netherlands
labDescription: At the Utrecht-BCI Lab we study the neuronal mechanisms underlying human brain function in order to understand the relationship between electrical, metabolic, cerebrovascular and neurochemical processes of neuronal populations on the one hand, and normal and abnormal behaviour on the other hand. To that end, we focus both on methodology, application in brain imaging research and on the development of neurotechnology. In particular, we developed implanted Brain-Computer Interfaces to restore communication in severely paralyzed individuals, with a focus on clinical impact and home-use.
currentResearchTopics: Implanted BCIs for children with complex needs
Identification of needs and interest in BCIs for Cerebral Palsy using user-centered design
Decoding hand movement from sensorimotor cortex

labDescription: My lab uses multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), functional near infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), and electroencephalography (EEG) to investigate neuroplasticity in children with early brain injuries (perinatal/childhood stroke, quadriplegic cerebral palsy, epilepsy, spinal muscular atrophy, preterm birth, traumatic brain injury, chronic pain). We also use personalized neuroimaging techniques to maximise effectiveness of brain stimulation and pediatric brain-computer interfaces (BCIs).
currentResearchTopics: Personalized multimodal neuroimaging
Normative modelling
Imaging sensorimotor networks in youth with quadriplegia

labDescription: At BCI4Kids, we provide children with severe neurological disabilities access to cutting-edge brain-computer interface (BCI) technology to help them achieve greater independence, realize new participation in life, and do things they never thought possible. Our vision is to build and grow a child- and family-centered program to bring BCI technology out of the research laboratory and into the lives of people and children in need.
currentResearchTopics: Clinical implementation research
Patient and family engagement in pediatric research
Structural and Functional imaging of children and adults with quadriplegic cerebral palsy
